reviewText:
I actually feel bad now about waiting to buy this for $20. This game is so much better than what I was expecting. The detail, my gosh, the detail. I was blown away by the opening screen, even. The menus are gorgeous and perfect for VR, the planes look amazing, and there is a surprising amount of variety in the gameplay.

This game is SO MUCH MORE than simply drawing flight routes for planes to land (a-la Air Control for mobile platform). That's what I was expecting, and it's there, but oh my, it's only a tiny part. This is a perfect example of a game that doesn't convey it's beauty from demo vids or pictures. Maybe consider releasing a short demo of the first mission? I bought this because it looked interesting, the dev seemed really nice from interviews before Vive release, and I really appreciated their communication about the initial sticker shock and subsequent price drop.

Had I known the game was this polished, with so much variety, I would not have cared about the aforementioned reasons for the purchase. This game is a blast, plain and simple. Can't wait to get out of work so I can get back to it!

Love planes? You'll probably really enjoy Final Approach. Me262 taxiing to the runway ready for take-off? Yes please

reviewText:
Final Approach offers a unique experience that demonstrates the incredible potential of the HTC Vive. Not only do you play a third-person strategy game where you serve the role as an aircraft controller, but you're able to warp down to ground level and do a few different mini-tasks such as putting out fires with a water hose, or throwing luggage into destination containers. The transition between third-person and first-person is downright remarkable, presenting a perspective that makes the world come to life.

Final Approach suffers from some repetition as with the entire HTC Vive launch line-up, but does present several missions that are moderate in length. Because of this, it is one of the games that I foresee offering some of the longest-duration play value.

I would recommend Final Approach as one of the top three options for HTC Vive launch as it's unique and should provide around four+ hours of entertainment.

You can read more about my impressions here: http://www.gamerevolution.com/features/final-approach-on-htc-vive-shows-how-multiperspective-vr-games-can-blow-your-mind

You start by directing slow aircraft on an island.  Then you move up to a commercial airport.  Then you direct helicopters in the middle of a metropolis.

In every stage you are able to get to the ground level to put out fires.  This includes fires on aircraft.  So, I actually got to stand on an aircraft carrier as a full-sized naval fighter jet taxied past me.  I felt like I could actually touch the sidewinder missiles!  I looked to the left to see ground crew prepping or repairing other fighters.

I can't describe how amazing this game is. It's like Thomas the train meets airplanes. The level of detail on all of the models is just incredible. At one point I just got down on my knees and admired the models letting the traffic crash into eachother. But you get a real sense of urgency when a plane or helicopter checks in on fire and needs to be put down asap. Its just staggering how enjoyable this game is. It makes you feel like a kid again, flying your toy airplane around, except its real.\nWould absolutely recommend this game to everyone.
It seems like such a simple idea...but it is so much deeper and more fun.\n\nI am supremely glad I took a chance on this.  The most polished and complete Steam VR game thus far!!

Simply beautiful. Probably the most immersive VR game I have seen.

1) Graphics : incredible - the level of details makes you look at all decos like you are in front of model toys. This really shows what VR can do.
2) Control : well made, intuitive, easy.
3) Gameplay : nice. This is not only an air trafic controller game, however. Better think of it like you are in front of a toy maquette and need to manage events. You will find yourself extinguishing fires, throwing bags in carts and scaring birds.

Bottom line : the graphics level of details is so fantastic that even if the rest was bad (but it is fantastic !), this game would still be worth looking at. In my opinion, this is one of the most polished VR game available now.

The premise is old but feels compleatly new here. I can feel very busy but calm playing this. Like a traffic cop, my arms going everywhere and my serious face on. There is a great deal of things to do in the game and events are a little random so it is different every time. Great graphics, audio and production value. The most compleate package aviailabe for Vive right now.

The knee-jerk reaction to this game is that it is just Flight Control in VR and while it is similar to that 2009 iOS game it quickly reveals it has a lot more going for it. The first island is about what you would expect, you guide planes to runways and try to avoid them crashing into each other. Sometimes a plane is on fire and you need to zoom down to play a quick mini-game to put it out, sometimes birds are on the runway and you need to scare them away with an airhorn.

The second level however starts to mix it up where you are in charge of a city airport with lots more runways, no birds to manage but a lot more stuff to juggle. You need to start planning which direction you want certain planes to land on the runway because if they need repairs they'll need to taxi over to one side of the airport while it's a military aircraft it needs to park in certain hangers. The third level isn't even at an airport.

It is enjoyable to pick an aircraft out of the air and draw a line to guide its approach. I've found the hands in this game to be a bit more jittery than in other games, not sure if that is a problem with my setup but it doesn't really affect gameplay.
Great game with wayyyyy more content and depth than it looks!

This is one of the most fun and addicting games I have played in VR to date.  It was actually one of the games I played on a demo Vive Pre that convinced me to preorder it.

Usually I don't write a whole lot of reviews but after getting further along in this game, I feel that I really need to offer it.  This is especially because this game gets a whole lot better as you move along.  The progress of the game allows you to learn and pick up skills.  Then it gets a lot more intense.

You start by directing slow aircraft on an island.  Then you move up to a commercial airport.  Then you direct helicopters in the middle of a metropolis.

The last stage I played convinced me to write this review.  You get to direct fighter aircraft to land on an aircraft carrier!  In every stage you are able to get to the ground level to put out fires.  This includes fires on aircraft.  So, I actually got to stand on an aircraft carrier as a full-sized naval fighter jet taxied past me.  I felt like I could actually touch the sidewinder missiles!  I looked to the left to see ground crew prepping or repairing other fighters.

There are some other incredibly fun things you can do in this stage but I think I have already provided enough spoilers!

Get this game.  It is beautiful, complete, and intense!

I haven't even played it for a full hour yet, and I can already say it's well worth the money. Graphics and level of detail are amazing, I've heard it has a good 6 or so hours worth of gameplay, with good replayability and challenges beyond that. The trailer doesn't really do it justice, the game is immersive and actually quite challenging. I look forward to getting better at this game, I appreciate the fact it actually has a learning curve. That fact alone adds depth to it.

Would recommend for younger players or those who enjoy time management games most definitely, it's a very well polished game and is fun for a bit.  But there is just no draw for me to play it past the one hour I already did play as I feel I know how to do everything already and no need to experience more.  maybe if it was a little more realistic, or more challenge involved I would give this an even higher recommendation.

reviewText: This is my favorite game for the HTC Vive so far.  I have most of the (better) current games for the Vive and most of those are really more like demos.  Final Approach however, seems like a polished, full game.  It is very entertaining and fun to play!\n\nI passed it over a few times because it didn't look like it would hold my attention for more than an hour or so.  After reading some of the reviews, I decided to try it.  I am very glad I did.  I play mostly off line, so my stats don't show it, but I have probably played this game for over 30 hours so far and it is still fun.

Super polished, super fun. 10/10. I was about to put the Vive on the shelf for a while after having gotten bored of wave-based EVERYTHING and 2 hour experiences. Im 2 hours in on this game, and have BARELY scratched the surface. They mix it up really well so its not just 'landing planes' and I feel this is up there with Job Simulator as a nicely finished and delivered game.\n\nI wish they had a little floor height adjustment for us tall folks, as I do have to bend a little bit sometimes, even when adjusting the room size in the settings.
